column8: avoids midday"	"The engineers who redesigned Japan’s Shinkansen bullet train indeed took inspiration from the beak of the Common Kingfisher (Alcedo atthis).

column1: In the late 1980s
column2: the Shinkansen 500 Series faced a major engineering problem — when the train exited tunnels at high speed
column3: it created a “tunnel boom”
column4: a loud shockwave caused by compressed air.

column1: Eiji Nakatsu
column2: the chief engineer on the project and a keen birdwatcher
column3: noticed that the Common Kingfisher dives from air into water with barely a splash
column4: thanks to its streamlined beak shape.

column1: By redesigning the train’s nose to mimic the long
column2: tapered beak of the kingfisher
column3: engineers:

column1: Eliminated the sonic boom
Reduced air resistance by ~30%
column2: and

column1: Improved energy efficiency by around 15%.
This example is a classic case of biomimicry — applying principles from nature to solve human engineering problems."	"The common kingfisher exhibits both resident and migratory behaviors

column1: Clutch Size: 2 to 10 glossy white eggs are incubated for ~ 20 days.
The common kingfisher primarily feeds on small fish.  Its natural diet also includes aquatic insects
column2: crustaceans like prawns
column3: and small amphibians such as tadpoles. It hunts from a perch 1–2 m (3–7 ft) above the water. From here it plunges steeply down to seize its prey usually no deeper than 25 cm (10 in) below the surface. The wings are opened underwater and the open eyes are protected by the transparent third eyelid. Kingfishers fly low and straight like bullets
column4: reaching up to 25 miles per hour. Their beaks are sharp
column5: pointed
column6: and so long that they make up a third of a kingfisher's height
column7: these beaks slice soundlessly through water meaning kingfishers can dive into pools without alerting fish."	"Which of the following adaptations helps the Common Kingfisher hunt effectively underwater?

column1: A. Its eyes can focus in both air and water
column2: and its long
column3: pointed beak reduces water resistance when diving.

column1: B. It closes its eyes underwater and relies only on its sense of touch to catch prey.
C. Its short
column2: curved beak helps it scoop up fish from the surface while hovering.

column1: D. Its large nostrils allow it to breathe underwater while chasing prey.
? A. Its eyes can focus in both air and water
column2: and its long
column3: pointed beak reduces water resistance when diving.

column1: Explanation:
The Common Kingfisher has special visual adaptations—it can adjust the curvature of its lens to focus clearly both above and below water. Its streamlined
column2: dagger-like beak enables swift
column3: precise dives with minimal splash
column4: helping it spear or grasp fish efficiently."	Plumage is a striking contrast of vibrant blue-green on its back and wings and reddish-orange on its underparts	Piscivore	Nil	Nil	C	Nil

column1: The Booted Eagle occurs in two distinct colour forms — pale and dark. What is the advantage of this variation?

column2: improving camouflage while hunting.

column1: ? B. It allows the species to blend into different habitats
column2: improving camouflage while hunting.

column1: Explanation:

The Booted Eagle shows color polymorphism — individuals may be pale (with light underparts and contrasting flight feathers) or dark (uniform brown). This variation helps them adapt visually to different environments
column2: from open grasslands to wooded or rocky regions
column3: offering better camouflage and hunting success."	There are two quite distinct plumage forms with the Booted eagle. This buzzard-sized eagle has a long tail to accompany its slender build.
